title: Did the Jews originally come from Mesopotamia since Abraham (if he is not a fictional character) was from there before immigrating to Canaan in The Levant? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes, we came from what is now northern Iraq. Abraham’s ancestors held the family lands in the region of the town of Harran, which still exists. From there, Terah moved south to Ur, and his son Abraham moved to what is now Israel. Ever was an early ancestor of Abraham (Genesis ch.10-11) and the earliest Hebrews were Abraham's uncles and cousins for several generations back. They were among the Western Semites and lived in northern Mesopotamia, near the confluence of the Balikh and the Euphrates. In 1934-39, excavations were conducted at ancient Mari on the Euphrates River. They found that ancient towns were named after the ancestors of Abraham: The city of Nahor was found near the city of Harran which exists to this day. Equally clear signs of early Hebrew residence appear in the names of other towns nearby: Serug (Assyrian Sarugi), Terah (Til Turakhi, "Mound of Terah"), and Peleg (Paliga, on the Euphrates near the mouth of the Habur). All these names are found in Genesis ch.11.

Well, if you believe Abraham was not a fictional character, you may as well believe he came from Mesopotamia, and that this is the source of the Jewish bloodline — after all, that is what the Bible says. However, nearly all historians say Abraham was a fictional character, so there is no real reason to believe the Jews originally come from Mesopotamia. To confirm this, nearly all historians also say that there was no Exodus from Egypt as portrayed in the Bible. You need both Abraham and Moses for the Jews to have originated in Mesopotamia, and you have neither. Based on archaeology, what appears to be the real truth is that the Hebrew people were actually rural Canaanites who left the region of the rich coastal cities to settle peacefully in the Levantine hinterland. So, they originally came from the coastal Canaanite lands before moving to the cisJordan hill country.

No. The Jews (and the Israelites) originated in Canaan. Hebrew is a Canaanite language, the older portions of the Tanakh most closely resemble Canaanite literature. We have archaeological evidence for the origin of the Hebrew tribes in the highlands of Canaan, up to and including the absence of pig bones in their middens.

Abraham came originally from Mesopotamia, Ur of the Chaldeans.Abraham, while the father of the Jews, and other nations, cannot be considered a Jew, since Jews are the descendants of Judah, who was Abraham's great-grandson. By the way Israelites are the descendants of Israel, who is the same as Jacob: Abraham's grandson and Judah's father.
